content_chunk: "# Goonj\nGOONJ the dramatic society of AKGEC representing the college in almost every dramatics domain including NUKKAD NATAK
column5: MIME
column6: STAND-UP
column8: HINDI DEBATE
column9: AD-MAD and many more. Consequently
column10: Goonj has been victorious in numerous events bringing glory to the College's name.\nDramatics is the learning and observing of various aspects in day to day life and bringing the results in the real world to bring change for the betterment of the society.\nGoonj is the dramatics society of Ajay Kumar Garg Engineering College which was founded in 2005. Dramatics is based truly on expressions whether it is for words or for acting. Goonj takes part in various fields of drama and has excelled in them. Nukkad natak is one of their main domain. They have always chosen burning social issues and been the mirror to the society. Apart from nukkad natak
column11: they enthusiastically take part in stage plays
column14: mime
column15:
monoact and many others. It is an actor’s job to grasp the full significance of life and this society truly proves it right.
**FB PAGE GOONJ- FOLLOW YOUR HEART :** <https://www.facebook.com/goonj.akg>
ACTIVITIES/EVENTS
#### THOMSO’24 in IIT Roorkee on 04-06 October 2024
We are elated to celebrate the outstanding achievements of our talented students who brought immense pride to our institution through their participation in renowned events such as Thomso’24 (IIT Roorkee). Congratulations to all students and mentors for their exceptional accomplishments that epitomize brilliance
column16: teamwork
column17: and passion for excellence!\nA `22’ members team of Goonj Society had participated in IIM Lucknow on 9th & 11th Feb 2023 and the following events held there:(a) Halla Bol (Mono – acting)(b) Antarnad (Stage Play)\nShubham Jha (3rd Year) did a mono-act based on “Therapy session of a mentally ill person” whereas Megha Jain (2nd Year) performed a mono-act based on “Revenge taken by a mother for injustice to her daughter”. Megha Jain was adjudged 1st runners up for fresh script and great acting whereas Shubham Jha got a special mention for excellent acting. Mono act competition was judged by Sh. Mir Sarwar
column18: an actor director of repute (Bajranngi Bhaiijaan)
column19: JollyLLB2
column20: The Family Man).\nIn the stage play category (Antarnaad) our play `Anbhigya’ was based upon the “Behavior of people towards HIV positive patients and the myths about the HIV AIDS”. It was one of the most realistic and practical play among all the participants
column21: with a great concluded moral value. When results of about 10 participating teams from various prestigious college / institutes were announced
column22: our team bagged 2nd prize and 1st prize was won by SRCC (DU). The judgment was based upon the direction
column23: screenplay
column24: dialogue delivery
column25: makeup-costume and time limit. Our play got full points in use of props and music
column26: great acting & clarity in dialogue delivery. The play was judged by Saurabh Sachdeva
column27: Actor & Actor Coach (Good Luck
column28: Jerry

He was presented with a certificate and a cash prize of INR 700/.\nContinuing with the winning performance

Maharastra ). The play was highly applauded by the audience.

"# Horizon
[ Home ](https://www.akgec.ac.in/departments/applied-sciences-humanities/)
[ Faculty ](https://www.akgec.ac.in/ash-faculty/)
[ Labs ](https://www.akgec.ac.in/ash-labs/)

[ Departmental Activities ](https://www.akgec.ac.in/ash-departmental-activities/)
""Exploring extremities and beyond""
“We are what we repeatedly do. Excellence
column5: but a habit."" – Aristotle\nA cadre of dynamic individuals
column6: possessing a diverse spectrum of aptitudes
column8: constitutes Horizon. The organization aspires to cultivate the technical and managerial sagacity of students
column9: equipping them to navigate perpetually.\nThe logo aptly expresses the goal of the society. The saffron area represents freedom of innovation
column10: ideas
column11: and intellect. The Steel Grey part represents determination
column13: and dedication. When these two areas converge
column14: any tough job becomes easier. The logo points towards both dimensions
column15: hence HORIZON – exploring extremities and beyond.\n### Vision\nThe global information and communication industry is rapidly advancing
column16: creating new career opportunities and challenges. In India
column17: there is a need for technical professionals who possess excellent communication skills
column18: management abilities
column19: and cutting-edge technology knowledge. Team Horizon aims to develop the technical and managerial acumen of students to prepare them for the industry's constantly evolving landscape.\n### Mission\nWe aim at creating technocrats
column20: entrepreneurs & above all Innovative minds with impeccable grit
column21: discretionary vision
column22: and effective leadership.● Bridging the gap between technical and managerial skills.● Exposure of students to the wider community.● Establishing a process that is independent of individual competence.● Providing a common platform to students
column23: irrespective of their backgrounds to initiate
column24: innovate
column25:
and explore new ideas under expert guidance and effective mentorship.
Faculty Coordinators
Dean 1st year
Prof. S.L. Kapoor 
Asst. Prof. Applied Science & Humanities Dept.
Mr. Vikas Roshan
Student Coordinators
(Head Coordinator)
Arjun Jain
(Head Coordinator)
Samriddhi Narayan
(Co-Head Coordinator)
Abhishek Verma
ACTIVITIES AND EVENTS
ANNUAL EVENTS
### 
Students Creative Oratory Learning Skills: An annual national technical event for voicing perceptions on pertinent topics of technology. SCROLLS was organized solely by Team Horizon.
The event
column28: featured two phases: Synopsis submission and Technical paper presentation. Students nationwide submitted synopses judged by faculty
column29: with selected teams presenting their research to expert panels during the final round on campus. The competition showcased innovative ideas
column30: included discussions on technical trends
column31: and provided a platform for knowledge sharing and networking. With prizes exceeding ₹1 lakh and AKGEC Skills Foundation coupons worth ₹7
column33: SCROLLS successfully promoted research
column34: innovation
column35: and academic growth.\n### \n‘KIRAN’ aims at making the students of 2nd
column36: 3rd & 4th years understand the ill effects of ragging
column37: the UGC anti-ragging guidelines
column38:
and the traumatic impact it leaves on the minds of the freshers. 
### 
‘Disha’ is an initiative towards introducing the freshers to the college culture and organization. It includes an address by the distinguished dignitaries of the college followed by a virtual tour of the college and a brief presentation by Horizon members.
DISHA
column39: the annual orientation program
column40: welcomed new students on September 11-12
column43: helping them transition into college life. The event featured sessions on college policies
column44: academics
column45: and campus life

the evening saw hostelers dressed in vibrant traditional attire dancing to Gujarati beats. 
EVENTS COVERED

On December 5

column70: the techno-managerial society of the College

column74: and technical fields on February 10
column76: and May 29

column78: the event honored students' dedication and inspired the college community to strive for excellence.\n### \nTeam Horizon's annual recruitment process ensures the society's growth by inducting new talent. This year’s recruitment was held in two phases: Spectrilia (April 20–May 11
column79: 2024) and Tessare (May 20–30
column81: with 60 in the wildcard round and 170+ in the recruitment round. Candidates underwent rigorous assessments of their skills

column92: food
column93: merchandise

column95: and a lucky draw. Team Horizon managed the event

column107: and a talent showcase. Organized and anchored by Team Horizon's second-year members
column108: the event fostered interaction between freshers
column111: it provided a warm introduction to college life and a sense of community for the newcomers\n### \nA nostalgic event for the final year students
column112: reminiscing all the memorable moments in college life.\nThe Farewell party
column116: was a heartfelt event organized by third-year students to honor the outgoing final-year batch. Managed by Team Horizon
column119: and performances by juniors. It was an emotional celebration of graduates' achievements and a moment of gratitude
column121: and anticipation for their future endeavors.\n### \nTeam Horizon organised the Model G20 summit on 24th March
column122: 2023. A literary fest incorporating multiple stages such as formal letter writing
column123: and group discussion followed by speech delivery to discuss some global issues.\n### \nTo untangle our emotions

column130:
and a quintessential person. 
### 
The Confederation of Indian Industry (CII) and Majestic Auto Limited orchestrated the 'SKILL-WILL-LEAD' intercollege competition. Team Horizon hosted and facilitated the entire event.

An inter-college annual sports meet to encourage the budding athletes of our college.
### 
Ajay Kumar Garg Memorial Table Tennis Tournament: The riveting tournament between players across the state to promote healthy sportsmanship.
### 
Every year

in good faith to help those in need.

A cultural show was organized for the NAAC Team visit to our college in 2023 to showcase cultural diversity. Team Horizon managed the event through anchoring and hospitality.

column134: 2024 showcasing their talent and perseverance. Our members won the Mayanagri Quiz and secured the Adjudicator Title in the Asian Parliamentary Debate. This success reflects their dedication and teamwork.\nTeam Horizon participated in the annual cultural festival of IIT Kanpur

This achievement not only underscores Radhika's literary prowess but also reflects the excellence that Team Horizon brings to such competitive platforms.\n### \nOur college organized an Anti-Ragging Poster Making Competition on December 8

content_chunk: "# Renaissance\nIntroduction\nThe society
column3:
Renaissance was formed in 2008 by three determined students who wished to 'bring a change' around themselves by being the change with the motto “BE THE CHANGE YOU WISH TO SEE”
The society derived its name from the cultural & social movement of Europe called 'Renaissance' which means 'Rebirth'. And hence we work together towards the 'Awakening of Consciousness'.
Intellectual education influences the individual mind and values-based education influences the heart. True education is the training of both the head and the heart.
Renaissance – “Awakening of consciousness” is the Ethical cum Patriotic Society of college.
We
column4:
as the only ethical society of college have donated clothes to the needy in the winters. We have organized numerous seminar in the college in order to highlight the ongoing social issues.
ACTIVITIES AND EVENTS
### 
On June 20
column6: Team Renaissance organized “एक युद्ध
column7: नशे के विरुद्ध"" at the CSIT seminar hall. The event focused on raising awareness about the dangers of drug addiction. It featured informative slides and impactful speeches by our orator
column8: providing a clear message against drug use.The highlight of the event was a live stream organized by NCB Lucknow
column9: which added an authoritative voice to the matter. This initiative aimed to educate attendees on the risks of drug consumption and encourage a drug-free lifestyle.\n### \nOn May 31
column11: Team Renaissance conducted Prayan 24
column12: a heartfelt farewell event for our fourth-year members. The evening began with a series of performances including music
column14: and drama presented by the junior students. The Director General delivered an inspiring speech
column15: highlighting the accomplishments and impact of the fourth-year students and offering words of encouragement for their future endeavours.\nThe event concluded with a grand feast
column16: allowing attendees to interact and reminisce. A heartfelt vote of thanks was given
column17: expressing appreciation to all participants and wishing the graduates the best in their future pursuits. Prayan 24 was a memorable and impactful event
column18: celebrating the accomplishments and cherished memories of the fourth-year students.\n### \nTeam Renaissance successfully conducted a blood donation camp on April 24
column20: in collaboration with the Rotary Blood Bank
column21: Noida. The camp witnessed tremendous participation with over 750 registrations
column22: including a large participation of faculty
column23: staff and students. A total of 609 units of blood were taken
column24: demonstrating the humble nature of our campus community. Due to the huge participation
column25: the club ran out of blood collection bags. The event not only proved how dedicated we are to protecting lives but also proved how powerful our teamwork was.\n### \nTeam Renaissance organized a Poster Making Competition themed “Save Lives
column26: Donate Blood"" as a key feature of the Blood Donation Camp
column27: aimed to raise awareness about the importance of blood donation and inspire community participation. \nThe competition witnessed enthusiastic participation from over 253 students
column28: each showcasing their creativity and commitment to the cause. \nThe posters were evaluated based on originality
column30: and artistic expression and the best ones were put on canvas in the main admin block
column31:
serving as a constant reminder of the noble cause and encouraging a compassionate response from viewers.
### 
Team Renaissance organized a pre-talk session on blood donation to underscore the importance of blood donation and its vital role in saving lives. The session aimed to educate and motivate participants about the critical need for regular blood donations.
Distinguished guest speakers
column32: Dr. Rachna and Dr. Deepak
column33: graced the event with their profound wisdom and expertise. They discussed the science behind blood donation
column34: and its life-saving potential
column35: and addressed common misconceptions.\nThe session concluded with an engaging Q&A
column36: where participants had the opportunity to interact with the experts. This initiative successfully heightened awareness and fostered a sense of responsibility towards regular blood donation among attendees.\n### \nUnder the guidance of our college
column37: Team Renaissance looked over the management and coordination part for the successful completion of the Table Tennis Tournament. This national-level tournament attracted sports enthusiasts from different regions of Haryana
column38: Delhi and Uttar Pradesh to compete for a prize pool of Rs. 1
column40: 000.\nAmidst fierce competition and spirited sportsmanship
column41: players showcased their skills and determination
column42: making each match a thrilling spectacle.\n### \nTeam Renaissance
column43: under the guidance of Shri Ram Saran Garg Indo-German Hospital
column44: organised an Anaemia Detection Camp to complement the awareness talk on the occasion of International Women’s Day. The camp was organised at the Girls' Hostel 3
column45: offering free screening to female students.\nThis initiative encouraged students to participate actively
column46: demonstrating their commitment to their health.\n### \nTeam Renaissance
column47: under the guidance of the college
column48: organised a talk on anaemia
column49: specifically for female students. The guest speaker for the day was Dr. Major Prachi Garg
column50: CEO of Shri Ram Saran Indo German Hospital. She addressed the crucial issue of anaemia
column51: providing valuable insights into its causes
column52: effects
column53: and preventive measures for women. \n### \nTeam Renaissance
column54: under the guidance of the college organised Vyomini'23
column55: which was a vibrant garba night organised in the AKGEC girls hostel to embrace the joy of Navratri with colourful attire
column56:
swirling skirts and lively camaraderie. To infuse a dose of joy and relaxation the society members of Team Renaissance organised an exuberant game “STACK THE CUP”.
### 
The fresher's party Navadhyay was organised for the latest batch. It was a retro theme-based event. All the cultural society along with the organising committee had made the event wonderful and exciting for everyone.
### 
The National Foundation for Communal Harmony (NFCH) annually observes the Communal Harmony Campaign Week from November 19th to 25th.To support the cause
column57: Team Renaissance prepared donation boxes across all academic departments
column58: facilitating a seamless fundraising process. ⁠The fund raised through this initiative was dedicated to supporting the Foundation's initiative for communal harmony.\n### \nTeam Renaissance
column59: under the guidance of the college
column60: orchestrated a delightful event called Fun Fanatics at the Deepawali Fair
column61: sparking a playful spirit among attendees. The event witnessed enthusiastic participation from over 180 students and faculty. Energetic faculty members and students actively engaged in activities like Pinata Smash and Balloon Bonanza
column62: crafting a vibrant tapestry of joy.\n### \nDisha (3rd and 4th October
column63: 2023) is a two-day annual event that introduces new students to the college's infrastructure
column64: programs
column65: and different cultural societies which helps to welcome students in a friendly atmosphere to encourage their creative impulses and boost their confidence. Team Renaissance
column66: with the support of other societies
column67: hosted DISHA
column68: an anti-drug campaign. This is a solemn commitment to foster a healthy and substance-free environment for academic commitment in our college\n### \nTeam Renaissance with the support of the college
column69: organised KIRAN – 2023 on 12th and13th September
column71: a two-day annual event which is ⁠dedicated to eliminating ragging and substance abuse on educational campuses and ⁠invites participants to join the noble journey against substance abuse and ragging.There were a total of 4 slots of oratory each day
column72: in which a total of 16 orators participated for 2 days. The event aims to promote laughter in the halls of learning instead of fear.\n### \nTambola
column73: also known as Bingo
column74: is a popular number-based game where participants mark off numbers on a card as they are randomly called out. The members of Team Renaissance organised Tambola as a fun recreational activity for seniors. Such activities can indeed help reduce stress for seniors and create a positive environment.\n  * 27th Km Milestone

content_chunk: "# Taal\nTaal is the dance society of AJAY KUMAR GARG ENGINEERING COLLEGE.\n“DANCE – you don’t start counting at 1
column6:
8.
You choreograph every song you listen to.
You practice dance routines under your desk.
You don’t walk places
column7: you dance there"".\nTaal comprises of innovative
column8: talented and versatile students as its coordinators and members. The society came into existence in the year 2004 with the aim of exploring the college students to move their body to the beats and rhythm of life.The team practices various dance forms and participates in different intra and inter college events. This enables us to explore the actual competitive world of dance
column9:
which intensifies the spirit of dancing within us.
**“We dance to express not to impress""**

content_chunk:
"# Verve
Verve Fashion Team
About Verve
V-Verve is the fashion society of our college. We are a society of like minded fashion enthusiasts who aim to help students find and develop their own unique style.
We put up fashion shows based on various themes. When one hears the term “fashion show"" one can't help but think of flawless models embellished with gorgeous dresses and makeup walking under the spotlight in their high heels. However
column3: what most people fail to see is that underneath that makeup and costumes simmer hours of rehearsals and meticulous conceptualizing of the themes that are portrayed.\nFrom designing the dresses and props to choreographing the show and preparing the soundtrack
column5: without any outside help and everything is done exclusively on the basis of the theme. And in the end
column6: our models sizzle the ramp with their confidence and glamour.\nOur shows are more than just a strut in stilettos. We do not talk
column7: we do not act and yet our shows shout out to the audiences about social issues like Drug abuse
column8: depression
column9: women empowerment
column10: LGBT etc.\nV-Verve will appeal to anyone with an interest in fashion whether it be designing
column11: modelling
column12:
photography or simply a love for creativity.
PARTICIPATION
IMS GHAZIABAD
Team V-verve participated in a salient
column14: and grand cultural fest MELANGE held at Institute of Management Studies (IMS) Ghaziabad
column15: and marked yet another milestone as it secured the FIRST position .The event witnessed substantial participation from a great deal of fashion teams from various institutes in Delhi NCR region. Our male modelS Varun Singh and Saloni Verma also won the best dressed male and female award. Mesmerized by the formations we were solicited to perform again.Yet another victory was added in the name of AKGEC.\nIMT GHAZIABAD\nTeam V-verve participated in a magnificent and riveting fest VOGUE IT
column16: PASSION 21’ held at Institute of Management Technology (IMT) Ghaziabad and customarily left footprints on the hearts of many. As our models walked through the stage with utmost poise & grace
column17: glazing confidence with their astonishing expressions along with their spectacular props
column18: the crowd hailed in appreciation.\nBITS PILANI\nTeam V-verve participated in a magnificent and riveting fest OASIS 22’ held at BIRLA INSTITUTE OF TECHNOLOGY
column19: PILANI and customarily left memorable imprints on the hearts of many. Verve was successful in qualifying the prelims and beat most of the colleges from Delhi NCR
column20: including colleges of Delhi university
column21: IPU etc. As our models walked through the stage with exceptional poise & grace
column22: ravishing confidence with their marvelous expressions along with their spectacular props
column23: the crowd hailed in appreciation and wonder. The theme
column24: tattoos
column25: props and dresses made a statement in the show and verve members were congratulated for successfully representing themselves in the finals by the judges as well as fellow teams.\nMNNIT ALLAHABAD\nTeam Verve marked yet another milestone as it secured the FIRST position at Motilal Nehru National Institute of Technology (MNNIT)
column26: Allahabad. When the team first graced the stage it was a battle amongst 19 teams for the first spot. Team Verve finally brought glory home after competing against the 6 qualifying teams. With Retro and Bollywood blazoned everywhere
column27: it was team Verve that took the spotlight by walking the ramp responsibly. They were the gallant brazens who shouldered the theme ‘Reincarnation’ which included raising social awareness about Drug abuse
column28: women empowerment and rights of the LGBT community. The judge
column30: Mr. India finalist 2015
column31: mesmerised by the performance
column32: personally congratulated Team Verve and also revealed that he couldn’t award negative marks to the team
column33: which is something he is very good at
column34: because he couldn’t narrow down even a single speck of imperfection. Team Verve was thus offered a cash prize of 25
column35: 000 INR. The next day was a cherry on the cake as the stills from the show made it to newspapers like ‘Dainik Jagran’ and ‘Hindustan times’.\nBITS GOA\nTeam Verve made history as it secured the THIRD position at Birla Institute of Technology (BITS)
column36: Goa. Competing with Team Verve in the final round were 6 teams which included teams like Hindu and NIFT
column37: some of the best known beaux minds. Team Verve
column38: with their invincible performance
column39: threw light upon social issues like women empowerment
column40: drug abuse and rights of the LGBT community. The proud win Team Verve was offered a photo shoot worth 80
column41: 000 INR which is everything a blooming fashion team could ever dream of. This victory added the golden feather to the hat of the team.\n  * 27th Km Milestone

Computer Society Of India
Introduction
The COMPUTER SOCIETY OF INDIA (acronym as CSI) was formed in the year 1965. Since its inception
column3: CSI has been paving the way for the IT industry to advance in the right direction. By indulging within itself most famous IT leaders
column5: CSI has been highly successful in setting highest benchmarks in the field of professional competence with high quality commitment. It has set up a remarkable example by providing high range of services and networking opportunities through workshops
column6: seminars
column7: conventions and courses in which major faces of the industry have actively participated and exchanged valuable knowledge and ideas.\nC.S.I. in A.K.G.E.C. Since CSI student chapter has evolved in AKGEC
column8: it has been one of the most active societies of the institute by organising events and workshops which have proven to be blockbusters in the college. The active image of the society becomes more prominent during the annual national level event
column9: The Initiative
column10: wherein the society asks students to provide solutions to the burning issues our country is facing. CSI AKGEC Chapter is known for its highly skilled team members
column11: and the efficiency & quality of the events and workshops that it conducts. Recently Team CSI conducted Java and Android workshop
column12: Ethical Hacking workshop which saw immense participation among the students! ### 
The Workshop of ReactJS “RENDER” was conducted from 5th May 2022 to 8th May 2022. The workshop process included the registration of students from the link given by us. The registration was open for all branches of 1st and 2nd year. The venue was Advance IT Lab 1 and Advance IT Lab 2 and timings are:5th May 2022 – Thursday 4:00 PM to 7:00PM6th May 2022 – Friday 4:00 PM to 6:00 PM7th May 2022 – Saturday 10:00 AM to 4:00 PM8th May 2022 – Sunday 10:00 AM to 4:00 PM

### 
The coding event of CSI was conducted on 13th February. The Coding Event process included the registration of students on the online link. The Coding Event was open for all branches. The Coding Event was conducted in CS/IT labs 3rd floor on an online platform “Hackerrank”. The Event saw massive participations from students and more 217 students participated in the event. The Coding Event included questions on various real-life problems. There were a total of 6 questions ranging from questions of easy level to advanced level. A total of 2 hours was given to the participants to solve respective problems using different Algorithms. Administrative and discipline issues were coordinated by CSI members. In each year
column44:
one winner and two consolation prizes were given with a prize money of Rs. 1000 (for winner) and Rs. 500 ( for consolation) along with certificates.
Topic: CODESHELLDate: 13th FebruaryVenue: CS/IT Labs from 4:00 PM to 6:00 PM
### 
CSI conducted a course on Node Js with Mongo DB from 12 Sept’2019 in Advance IT Labs. A total of 40 students got registered online and participated in this course. The classes in the workshop were conducted mainly by CSI-AKGEC student chapter members. Other administrative and discipline issues were coordinated by other CSI members. In this workshop students first learned about the basics of web designing i.e. HTML5

As a final assessment on the last day we conducted a MCQ based test.\nStudents were also provided with a link to download the entire study material of the course. Live coding was done in the workshop and students implemented everything they learned under the guidance of our coordinators.\nDates: 12th – 28th Sept’2019Prizes

content_chunk: "# ISTE\nIndian Society for Technical Education\nThe Indian Society for Technical Education (ISTE) is a national
column4: non-profit making Society registered under the Societies Registration Act 1860. It was first started in 1941 as the Association of Principals of Technical Institutions (APTI) and converted into “Indian Society for Technical Education"" in 1968 with a view to enlarge its activities to advance the cause of technological education.The major objective of ISTE is to assist and contribute in the production and development of top quality professional engineers and technicians needed by the industries and other organisations.\nBeing the only national organisation of educators in the field of Engineering and Technology
column5: ISTE effectively contributes in various missions of the Union Government. The Ministry of Human Resource Development
column6: AICTE/DST/MIT/State Govts. are well associated with the ISTE for programmes related to technical education.\nISTE is a professional organization basically comprising of academicians
column7:
faculty & students of countrywide engineering colleges. ISTE is primarily setup for promotion of higher studies & technical education and carries out (directly or through its various chapters) the following activities:
  * Publication of bi – monthly magazine / newsletter.
  * ISTE / AICTE sponsored courses / seminars on relevant and state-of-the-art subjects/ topics through summer / winter schools / workshops.
  * Holding of annual National Convention of faculty / students.


  * Conduct of national Seminar regarding awards of faculty / students for technical competence / innovation / research work done.
  * Awards of best M.Tech. thesis in various branches of engineering.
  * Best student of each chapter award
column8:
annually.


Faculty and student Chapter of ISTE been functional in the college from july 2015 onwards. ISTE students have been actively involved in organizing and coordination of ISTE activities. The ISTE students organized an Inter College Technovation in four different domains on 8 April 2017 during the Even Semester (2016-17).
The ISTE students organized a workshop on Promotional Activities for Entrepreneurship during the academic year. The Chapter organized an inter college “ISTE Symposium 15” on 21 Feb 2015. The symposium provided a common platform to engineering students of various streams of the engineering colleges of NCR to think and act towards providing
column9: designing and structuring the various concepts/ideas to make India’s villages situated in coastal areas
column10: hilly terrain and plain land
column11: the real smart ones.\nISTE Student Chapter of AKGEC aims at enlarging its activities to advance the cause of quality technical education in the college. Providing guidance and training to students to develop better learning skills
column12: pleasing personality and industry ready engineering professionals
column13: are the key result areas of the College ISTE Student Chapter. For efficient and result oriented functioning of the society
column14:
interview is conducted every year to select society coordinators from all the engineering branches of the college . The society is presently having 422 members from all the branches of the college.

content_chunk: "# SAE India\nSAE International\nInitially established as the Society of Automotive Engineers founded in 1905
column4: globally active [professional association](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Professional_association) for engineering professionals in various industries. Principal emphasis is placed on [transport](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transport) idustries such as [automotive](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automotive_industry)
column5: aerospace
column6: and [commercial vehicles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commercial_vehicle). SAE International has more than 1
column8: 000 active members round the globe.\nSAE INDIA\nFounded in 1994
column9: is an affiliate society of [SAE International](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SAE_International)
column10: registered as an Indian non-profit engineering and scientific society dedicated to the advancement of mobility community in India. As an individual member driven society of mobility practitioners
column11: SAE INDIA comprises members who are individuals from the mobility community
column12: which includes engineers and executives. Principal emphasis is placed on transport industries such as automotive
column14:
and commercial vehicles. SAE India holds a variety of competitions every year for engineering students across the country.
**SUPRA SAE India Student Formula**
**EFFI Cycle**
### 
AACAR Workshop 2024
SAE AKGEC successfully organized Aacar 9.0
column15: an automotive workshop held on May 18-19
column16: 2024. This event provided participants with an extensive understanding about automotive technology
column17: covering topics from basic principles to advanced concepts. Attendees also gained valuable hands-on experience in one of the best-equipped labs
column18: thanks to our collaboration with BOSCH Lab (JCC and EBCS).\nFeedback from participants was extraordinary
column19: highlighting how much they learned from the workshop. A notable highlight was the practical demonstration led by female members of SAE AKGEC
column20: where they skillfully overhauled and showcased the Maruti Suzuki K12MN engine. This session broke stereotypes and motivated female participants to pursue careers in the automotive industry. Esteemed faculty and alumni of AKGEC attended the event
column21: sharing valuable insights and experiences from the industry.\nThe workshop concluded with a quiz based on the content covered
column22:
where winners were awarded cash prizes from SAE AKGEC and privilege cards from AKGEC Skills.
SAE AKGEC extends heartfelt gratitude to Ajay Kumar Garg Engineering College and AKGEC Skills for their invaluable collaboration and support.
AACAR Workshop 2023
The SAE Collegiate Club AKGEC organized the AACAR 8.0 workshop on 13th and 14th May 2023
column23: with the primary aim of fostering awareness about automobiles among junior participants. The event
column24: held in the Main Seminar Hall
column25: focused on providing participants with comprehensive theoretical knowledge about automobile components and systems
column26: supplemented by practical demonstrations. With SAE's commitment to engineering innovation
column27: the workshop aimed to bridge the gap between theoretical learning and practical application.\nOver the two-day workshop
column28: participants were immersed in a rich learning experience. Theory sessions covering chassis
column30: transmission systems
column31: engine
column32: suspension
column33: steering and electronic system. Practical demonstrations included the disassembly and reassembly of Maruti's K12MN engine
column34: showcasing the inner workings of the engine
column35: featuring demonstrations of Ambassador's gearbox overhaul
column36: braking system functionality
column37: and chassis concepts using a Swift Dzire
column38: along with presentations on power steering and electronic components. The event concluded with a quiz competition and introductions of mentors and coordinators
column39: fostering a holistic learning experience.\nIn conclusion
column40: the AACAR 8.0 workshop successfully delivered a comprehensive understanding of automobile systems through theoretical sessions and hands-on demonstrations. The event not only deepened participants' knowledge but also inspired them to think innovatively and practically
column41: aligning perfectly with SAE – AKGEC's commitment to promoting engineering creativity and application.\n**AACAR :-** The main agenda of the workshop is to provide the students with a deep insight into the exciting world of automobiles. The workshop is about making students aware of the possibilities and advancements that can be achived and the multi domain innovation in the world of cars. The workshop is orgnised in the month of FEB. of every year.\n**INNOVACION :-** The workshop challenges young minds to learn
column42: compete and provides a platform to be an innovator. The workshop is about making students aware of the possibilities that exist with micro-controllers (Arduino) and Sensors. We want to encourage the students to think
column43:
create and be the change maker. The workshop is orgnised in the month of FEB. of every year.
### 
SUPRA 2023
SAE Collegiate Club AKGEC Team Bravado Motorsport participated in the SAE-INDIA SUPRA 2023
column44: A National level engineering student competition organized by Maruti Suzuki India
column45: during 10th July -13th July 2023 at Buddh International Circuit. Teams from various engineering colleges from all over India participate and engage in designing and fabricating open wheel formula-style vehicles powered by 610cc engines. The event provided a platform for young engineers to gain hands-on experience and compete in technical inspections
column46: static (presentation-based) events
column47: and dynamic challenges. The day wise description of the event is as follows.\nDay 1 & 2
column48: after registration and paperwork
column49: the team set up in their designated pit area to prepare the vehicle for the Technical Inspection (TI) round. The TI round assessed vehicle safety and adherence to rules. involved multiple rounds of technical inspections. The team worked diligently to meet the stringent criteria
column50: leading to a successful technical inspection by the end of the day.\nDay 3 marked the noise and brake tests
column51: essential for qualification. Despite initial challenges with the engine
column52: the team's perseverance prevailed
column53: but an electrical fault during the noise test barred them from dynamic events and the endurance run. Despite setbacks
column54: the team demonstrated sportsmanship at the award ceremony and shared valuable takeaways.\nWhile not achieving their intended goal
column55: Team Bravado Motorsport's experience at SUPRA 2023 provided a foundation for growth and improvement in future competitions. The event showcased the dedication of young engineers and their commitment to pushing their limits within the realm of automotive innovation.\nBravado Motorsport\nTeam Bravado Motorsport is the premier Formula SAE team of AKGEC. It was built under the foundation of combining the simple ideals of innovation
column56: clever design
column57: and manufacturing to the highest caliber.\nEven though having a successful competition is our end goal
column58:
our primary focus is to give our members a fun engineering and team experience to prepare for their futures in the workforce developing a fearless attitude and being ready to face any challenges.
Our motto is “Brave Like Bravado “!!
Members:
Utilizing a state-of-the-art machine shop & Fronius Welding Centre available in our college and a highly skilled team of dedicated engineering students
column59: who are not only from Mechanical but also from Electrical/Electronics
column60: IT
column61: and CS domains
column62: we mainly participate in SUPRA and Effi-cycle(Effi-Que) events to showcase our skills.\nThe Effi-Que was organized this year from 22nd November to 25th November 2022
column63: at Lovely Professional University
column64: Jalandhar
column65: Punjab.Our team consists of various domains: Suspension & Chassis
column67: Transmission
column68: Steering
column69: Electrical & Powertrain
column70: and Project Management & Media. Each one has its projects that contribute to the team running smoothly and completing our car; you can find some of their work showcased here
column71: on our website
column72: or our Instagram!\n**EFFICAR :-** A fuel-efficient car conserves fuel by means of its construction and forward-thinking technologies
column73: including a variety of advanced power train designs. Vehicle construction can be a major factor in fuel efficiency. A fuel-efficient car design often includes sturdy yet lightweight materials that help reduce the vehicle's overall weight. Lighter vehicles require less power for movement
column74: thus consuming less fuel than heavier models.\n**EFFICYCLE :-** EFFI-CYCLE derived from Efficient-Cycle promotes the objective of providing opportunity to the students to conceive
column75: design and fabricate a three-wheel configuration vehicle powered by human-electric hybrid power and capable of seating two passengers catering to the day to day mobility needs. The vehicle must be aerodynamic
column76: engineered for performance & safety and ergonomically designed. The objective is to promote innovation and generate consciousness amongst the young engineers towards environment friendly mobility solution. The student of have won the grade ability award in 2017.\n**SUPRA :-** SAEINDIA
column77: the Indian chapter of the Society of Automotive Engineers
column78: has been organizing the event for its sixth consecutive year
column79: which sees students from engineering colleges across the country battle it out against each other in their quest to apply their technical knowledge on the ground by conceptualizing and developing a formula racing car. Guided by a standard rule book
column80: the Formula Supra requires teams to build a single-seat race vehicle
column81: using an engine having a maximum capacity of 610cc. With numerous other guidelines over the construction
column82: dynamics and safety of the vehicle
column83: students attempt their hands at designing the car by utilizing various computer aided tools like CATIA
column84: Unigraphics
column86:
etc. The student of have won the Best INNOVATION Award in 2016
### 
  * FIRST Runner-up at International Go-Kart Championship (2015)
  * Dronacharya Award (SAE Supra 2015)
  * BEST CAE Award (Effi-car
column87:
2016)


  * Best INNOVATION Award (SAE Supra 2016)
  * SECURED 20th POSITION AMONG 105 TEAMS AT SAE-NIS EFFI-CYCLE 2016 (FIRST TIME PARTICIPATION).
  * The student of have won the GRADEABILITY award in 2017.

content_chunk: "# National Conference -Mechanical and Automation Engineering (MAAE-2020)\nDepartment of Mechanical Engineering AKGEC organized the conference Mechanical and Automation Engineering (MAAE-2020)
column3: during 7-8 February 2020. The aim of the conference was to provide a knowledge sharing platform for researchers
column4: academicians and industry personnel. The conference also provided an opportunity to students to get exposed to the culture of academic development and to the field of research and innovation.\nResearch papers were invited on topics including Unconventional Manufacturing
column5: Automation & Robotics
column6: product Development and PLM
column8: Mechatronics
column9: Additive Manufacturing
column10: Flexible Manufacturing System
column11: Concurrent Engineering
column12: Simulation and Modelling and more.\nThe patrons and organizers were honored to have senior academicians from IITs
column13: NITs and other eminent technical institutions on the Technical and Advisory Board of the Conference.\nAir Marsal R.K.S. Shera
column14: PVSM
column15: AVSM
column16: VSM (Retd.)
column17: graced the opening ceremony as the Chief Guest
column18: Dr. P.C. Pant
column19: Director
column20: HRD Innovative Projects
column21: Ministry of New and Renewable Energy
column22: was the Guest of Honour and Dr. Rajeev Agrawal
column23: Associate Professor and Associate Dean (Research)
column24: Malaviya National Institute Of Technology
column25: Jaipur
column26: was the Key Note Speaker. The opening ceremony was attended by Director General AKGEC Dr. R.K. Agarwal
column27: Heads of Departments
column28: Deans
column30: delegates and the students.\nDr. Devender Singh
column31: HoD Mechanical Engineering and Convenor of the Conference
column32: introduced the theme of the Conference by sharing his industrial experiences.\nDr. R.K. Agarwal
column33: Director General AKGEC
column34: welcomed the guests and the participants and expressed his views on the various aspects of Automation. He conveyed his best wishes to the participants and urged them to use the conference as a great opportunity for learning and sharing.\nThe Chief Guest R.K.S. Shera made note of his illustrious career at the Indian Air Force and pointed out the opportunities and challenges that engineers can find in a career at the IAF. He urged the budding engineers to join the Indian Air Force for a fruitful career and service to the Nation.\nDr. P.C. Pant
column36: deliberated on his personal experiences in the field of renewable energy and its importance in Automation and Robotics. Keynote Speaker Dr. Rajeev Agrawal
column37: deliberated on Automation
column38: the theme of the Conference
column39: and further extended his talk to Autonomation – ‘Automation with human intelligence’ wherein machines can be made capable to predict defects. He sighted various case studies on Autonomation and advised the students and faculty to explore it as a new field for research.\n45 papers were received from academicians and researchers from institutions including IIM Kolkata; YMCA
column40: Faridabad; NIT Jamshedpur; Rajkiya Engineering College
column42: Navi Mumbai; Thapar Institute of Engineering and Technology
column43: Patiala and Colleges affiliated to Dr. A.P.J. AbdulKalam Technical University
column44: Lucknow. 36 papers were selected for presentation and inclusion in e-proceedings after a blind peer review process.\nThe conference ended with the valedictory function. Certificates and conference CDs were presented to the participants.\n  * 27th Km Milestone

content_chunk:
"# T&P Department
**Dr. Rakesh Srivastava**
**Dean – Training & Placement**
E-mail: tpo@akgec.ac.in
AKGEC has established itself as an institution par excellence
column3: dedicated to provide students with a strong scientific
column4: technical and humanistic foundation and encourage them to develop creativity in indentifying problems and seeking solutions. What distinguishes AKGEC from other institutions is the unswerving commitment towards producing professionals of outstanding quality and to transform students into professionals and technocrats who will stand tall amongst the crowd.\nTRAINING\nWith the mission to serve society by promoting excellence in education AKGEC aims to produce sound technical professionals with a temperament of strong logic. For this
column5: special efforts are made to groom students to meet the standards of industry
column6: both in technical knowledge and in soft skills. There is continuous college-industry interface and interactive seminars on emerging technologies are organised regularly to provide a holistic exposure to the students.\nThe college is part of the Campus Connect Program of Infosys for training students in accordance with the needs of industry. The college also conducts specialized courses for CAD packages like PRO-E.\nThe college helps students in undergoing industrial training for 04-06 weeks (2nd year Mechanical & 3rd year students of all branches) in reputed companies like BHEL
column8: Samsung Software
column9: Genpact
column10: HCL
column11: NTPC Dadri
column14: etc.\nBesides this
column15: AKGEC strives to inculcate responsibility and accountability in its students; responsibility towards their organizations and accountability towards society. The college conducts a Personality Development Program which enhances soft skills of the students
column16: builds their self-confidence and motivates them to scale new unbound heights of glory.\nWe imbibe in our students values of self-discipline
column17: decision making
column18: cultural closeness & moral resurgence and above all we try to reap good citizens and human beings.\nPLACEMENT\nAKGEC believes that each student is a valuable resource. The placement cell focuses on each student to maximize his/her career prospects and assists him/her in achieving the same. Students are placed through campus recruitment programs. The Training and Placement Cell is committed to fulfilling the dreams of all those who graduate from A.K.G. Engineering College. Objective of the placement cell is to place students in good companies. This is achieved through campus selections conducted in the college for which the students are trained in aptitude
column19: technical and soft skills
column20: much ahead of campus selections. The Cell believes in overall development of the students’ personality
column21: which will help them to achieve a rewarding career.\n  * 27th Km Milestone

content_chunk:
"# T&P Programmes
### PROGRAMMES FOR STUDENTS
PERSONALITY DEVELOPMENT PROGRAMMES (PDP)
Academic excellence alone is not enough and cannot guarantee a good career. Certain personality attributes and soft skills are essential not only to get a good job but also to be able to contribute and grow in an organization. Taking cognizance of this
column3: the college emphasises all round development through a range of extracurricular activities as well as organizing and conducting formal Personality Development Program.\nThis programme spanning over 100 hours is conducted by a professional agency and includes training in communication skills
column5: interpersonal skills and interviews. This is a mandatory programme for second year B.Tech. and MCA students of the college. This programme helps in the overall personality development of students. The whole exercise is intended to increase the employability of students. Amidst an inspiring and invigorating environment
column6: students undergo training that turns them into top notch professionals.\nINFOSYS CAMPUS CONNECT PROGRAM\nAs a step towards grooming students into perfect professionals and to make them compatible with the IT industry
column7: Infosys campus connect programme (Springboard) is run by T&P department which is conducted by Infosys. Under this programme
column8: Infosys train some identified faculty on emerging courses under Faculty Enabled Program (FEP). In this program B. Tech III year CSE
column9: IT students undergo training on emerging certification courses by Infosys on Springboard platform under the guidance of trained faculty.\nThese steps not only help Infosys to reduce their in-house training time but also help the students in acquiring technical skills which make them more suitable for IT industry.\n**The entire educational process at AKGEC revolves around guiding and providing the students all the imperative and relevant inputs to take on the professional world with conviction and confidence. Thus apart from PDP & Infosys CCP (Springboard) our college also offers modules on ProE
column10: CAT/A etc. leading to certification and helping students to become proficient in the current generation CAD software used in industry.**\n  * 27th Km Milestone

content_chunk: "# AKGEC International Journal of Technology\nAjay Kumar Garg Engineering College commenced publication of a biennial Technical Journal in 2010 to disseminate information spanning the entire spectrum of engineering and technology. We envisioned that this activity will help unleash the creative potential of technical community and provide a credible platform to receive professional recognition. Our journey through this arduous path has been a satisfying effort. We have sustained interest and support of the country’s Technical community.\nThe Journal aims to provide platform to researchers
column5: industry experts and authors interested in state-of-the art and state-of-the-practice activities via publishing their research-based papers
column6: articles and case studies on topics of current concern in the areas of engineering branches
column8: electronics
column9: communication technology
column10: instrumentation and measurement
column11: information technology
column14: robotics and allied disciplines.\nOur source of articles mainly comprises the faculty teaching in Engineering Colleges across the country. Process of publication of the Journal is supervised by IIT-background professionals with impeccable credentials. The articles are blind-peer reviewed and published following internationally-accepted IEEE style as the format for publication. Printed on art paper
column15: the Journal with ISSN number 0975-9514 is currently running in its Ninth volume. To begin with we had planned the Journal at the national level. Gradually
column16: the contributions started coming from overseas Universities and we converted it to an international journal.\nTo recognize the invaluable Intellectual contribution made by professionals in advancing the noble cause of dissemination of scientific and engineering knowledge
column17: all published articles since Volume 7 of the “AKGEC International Journal of Technology” are being suitably rewarded. A prize of Rs.5
column18: 000 is being paid to the paper adjudged the best for each issue. For the balance
column19: an amount of Rs.2
column20: 500 per article is earmarked.\nDr. R. K. Agarwal\nB.Tech (IIT Kanpur)
column21: M.S. (CIT
column22: Cranfield
column23: UK) and PhD (IISc Bangalore)\nDr. R.K. Agarwal has an exceptionally brilliant academic background with B.Tech from IIT Kanpur
column24: M.S. from CIT
column25: Cranfield
column26: UK and PhD from IISc Bangalore. During his illustrious career of nearly three decades in the Indian Air Force and Defence Research & Development Organization (DRDO)
column27: he has held various key appointments including Chief Engineering Officer of an Operational Base
column28: Director (Engg) at Air HQ and Project Director at Centre for Airborne Systems. His vast managerial
column30: research and academic experience includes teaching assignments at Air Force Technical College and nine years of pioneering R&D work on the prestigious AWACS project in DRDO. He has also been a member of the Aeronautical Research & Development Board (ARDB) panel for approval and review of sponsored research projects at various centres of Excellence established at IITs and CSIR Laboratories.\nHe is the recipient of the coveted Royal Aeronautical Society (UK) award for academic excellence at CIT and a citation with cash award by DRDO for his contribution to the design and development of Airborne Early Warning aircraft
column31: culminating in its maiden flight.\nAfter taking voluntary retirement in 2004
column32: Dr. Agarwal decided to contribute in the field of technical education and has been the Director of Ajay Kumar Garg Engineering College (AKGEC)
column33: Ghaziabad since then. He has been persistently working towards setting new benchmarks in academic excellence as well as industry–academia interface to make the students globally competitive and employable. During his tenure
column34: the college has not only been consistently maintaining exceptional results and placements but has also made significant progress in research and industry relevant consultancy projects. A number of initiatives and collaborative ventures with eminent multi-national companies have lead to establishment of many multi-disciplinary
column35: high technology industry relevant facilities. These include India’s first Kuka Industrial Robotics Training Centre
column36: NI-LabVIEW Academy
column37: Bosch Rexroth Centre of Competence in Automation Technologies
column38: Janatics Industrial Pneumatic Knowledge Centre and Mitsubishi Electric India. The college has also achieved the unique distinction of receiving the Academic Excellence Award for Best Engineering College in UPTU for two successive years under his able guidance.\nHe has also contributed in bringing about a culture of corporate social responsibility in academic institutions. The social activities initiated by him include running a free primary school in the college
column39: adopting a municipal corporation school in a nearby village
column40: providing tuition fee subsidy to children of class IV employees
column41: donating computers to spread computer literacy and generously contributing for relief work after natural calamities. Involvement in these activities makes the students conscious of their civic and social responsibilities. He places special emphasis on all round development with focus on inculcating self-discipline
column43: ethics
column44: work culture and a positive attitude to make the students not just competent professionals but also good citizens and responsible members of the society.\nHis wide ranging experience
column45: vision and dynamism have infused inspiration and provided a road map for academic institutions to achieve the zenith of excellence in all fields of activities.\nDr. R.K. Agarwal’s extraordinary inspiring-vision catapulted AKGEC to numero uno position for all time to come. He took the momentous decision in 2010 to launch this biannual publication to nurture creativity and encourage innovations. The journal received manuscripts even from overseas authors
column46:
earning accolades from research community worldwide.
Loading...
Dr Ranjit Singh
B.Tech
column47: M.Tech & Ph.D (IITK)\n**Dr Ranjit Singh** (b. 17 Aug 1948) obtained B.Tech
column48: M.Tech. and Ph.D degrees from Indian Institute of Technology
column49: Kanpur in 1969
column50: 1971 and 1975 respectively specializing in the area of Electronic communication circuits and devices.\nCurrently
column51: he is Editor-in-Chief of the _‘AKGEC International Journal of Technology’_
column52:
which is running in ninth volume.
Published large number of technical papers in IETE journals in addition to in-depth technology-reviews covering emerging trends in Communications and information technology. He was Editor at IETE during 1975-1987; Technical Editor at ‘Telematics India’ during 1987-2001; Editor of Industrial Purchase journal during 2002- 2008.
He has abiding passion for teaching and research. Guided 10 M. Tech and 2 PhD scholars besides supervising 15 B.Tech projects. Delivered Keynote address on ‘Mobile Computing’ in Feb 2014 at Annual Convention of JIMS.
He is Life Fellow of the IETE and attended international conferences held in France
column53: Singapore
column54: USA
column55: Hong Kong and Nepal. Daily practices advanced ‘Art-of-Living’ meditation. Also associated with ‘Amway’ and Insurance sector.\n**Contact Details :** +91 9868041558Email Id : editor_journal@akgec.ac.in
column56:
akgec.ece@gmail.com
**Invitation for Manuscripts concerning engineering subjects for publication in the AKG International Journal of Technology**
The “AKG International Journal of Technology” i.e. AKGIJT is a peer-reviewed journal published by Ajay Kumar Garg Engineering College (AKGEC). The AKGEC is among the top rung technical institutions situated in the Nationals Capital Region of India in Ghaziabad. The AKGEC is committed to provide world class education and research in the cutting-edge areas and has developed industry scale innovation centres in the frontline technologies. The Institute’s modern infrastructure attracts the industry to supplement training and research. The AKGIJT lives up to the vision of AKGEC and publishes peer review articles in the broad areas of Engineering & Technology involving all major disciplines for the last 13 years. The Journal has so far successfully published 14 biannual volumes and archived all the issues online with free accessibility in pdf format.
The AKGIJT invites scientific articles
column57: original research
column58: state of the art reviews and case studies from the industry
column59: research and academic professionals for consideration of publication in this open access (without APC) journal. The submitted articles will be peer-reviewed and further consideration will follow the review report/recommendations. Submissions will be peer-reviewed by a panel of experts.\n**Contributions in the broader contemporary research involving broad engineering disciplines and multi-disciplinary areas are welcomed.**\nBrief submission guidelines are given below
column60: but the prospective authors are encouraged to visit the Journal's website .The journal regards high value to the publication ethics and plagiarism. Detailed information for the authors including manuscript preparations
column61:
publication ethics and journal overview can be viewed on the Journal’s website.
All Contributions Should be Emailed to **[editor_journal@akgec.ac.in](https://www.akgec.ac.in/rd/akgec-international-journal-of-technology/editor_journal@akgec.ac.in)**
**Submission guidelines:**
• Submissions should be original and must not be under consideration for publications elsewhere.• The authors must include a statement of originality& similarity
column62:
conflict of interest and funding information.• The articles are generally limited to 3000 word and an abstract of 200 words.• The manuscript must include a list of at least three keywords.• The manuscript should be preferably composed in the MS Word format and equations should be typed in Equation Editor (and must not be pasted as image). The table and figures should be sequentially numbered and the legend must be separately included. The images should be of at least 300 dpi quality.• All references should be listed and cited in the text as per IEEE format.

content_chunk: "# Big Data Centre of Excellence\nIntroduction\n**“Big Data Centre of Excellence""** is the Research and Development centre of AKGEC. It is the first “Centre of Excellence"" in AKTU
column3: working in the field of BigData. It was established in 2013 and since 4 years it has been motivating and guiding the students into the world of Big Data. Big Data is the most trending technology of 21st century. It is the hottest market currently. Companies require Big Data Analysts to analyze the large amount of data being generated and gain insights from the data. Businesses are focusing more on agility and innovation
column4:
adopting BigData technologies help the companies achieve that in no time. The team aspires to develope skills in Big Data and gradually move from Machine Learning to Deep Learning and finally Artificial Intelligence.

column18: the centre is progressing tremendously
column19: winning several online competitions as well as intercollege competitions in Big Data domain. The members of the centre participate in teams also and compete on national level.\nMost fascinating and knowledge earning activity is **“Knowledge Transfer Session”** that takes place every week in the lab itself. During this session
column20: the members share their knowledge on a topic
column21: with other members and also clarify the doubts so that all members stand on the same level. This creates a very interesting and motivating environment in the lab itself.\n**_RUSH HOUR_**\nBig Data Centre of Excellence the research and development society of AKGEC successfully organized a one-day offline coding contest
column22: “RUSH HOUR” for second-year students in IT labs on 30th November 2023. The event was successfully conducted on the Hacker rank platform. A total of 120 students from the second year participated in the event. The participants were registered in a team of two
column23:
where each team worked on solving problems and earned points. The least scoring teams got eliminated every few minutes and the last three standing teams were declared the winner.
The top three teams of the event are to be awarded with cash prizes.

content_chunk:
"# Cloud Computing Cell
Cloud Computing Cell
Introduction
The Cloud Computing Cell
column4: has been a part of Ajay Kumar Garg Engineering College since February 2016. The members are exposed to the latest cloud technologies
column5: enabling them to be market-ready
column6: thereby increasing their opportunities in placements and research. It provides a platform for students to compute
column8: and deploy cloud-based solutions. The Cell is coordinated by Mr. Santosh Kumar Mishra and Ms. Shikha Agarwal
column9: faculty members of the IT department.\nCloud computing is a growing computing technology that provides almost unlimited computing resources on demand. It integrates various technologies such as IoT
column10: Big Data
column11: and Fog computing. Cloud users can access data
column13: and storage with minimal management of the local environment. It can be understood as a delivery model that provides computing services similarly to how a power grid supplies electricity.\nThe Cloud Computing Cell has successfully installed a private cloud using Apache CloudStack. CloudStack operates on the Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) model
column14: where the services include fully virtualized computers capable of performing computations similar to local machines.\nThe members gain hands-on experience with cutting-edge cloud technologies
column15: equipping them with the skills needed for both research and industry opportunities. By working on real-world implementations
column16: they enhance their expertise in computing
column17: managing
column18: and deploying cloud-based solutions
column19:
making them well-prepared for future career prospects.
Faculty Coordinators
Assistant Professor. IT Dept 
Mr. Santosh Kumar Mishra 
Assistant Professor. IT Dept 
Ms. Shikha Agarwal 
Student Coordinators
CSE
Raghav Agarwal 
CS
Priti Kapoor 
Year wise Sessional Reports
[ 2022-23 ](https://www.akgec.ac.in/wp-content/uploads/2023/05/CCC-2022-23.pdf)
[ 2021-22 ](https://www.akgec.ac.in/wp-content/uploads/2023/05/CCC-2021-22.pdf)
[ 2020-21 ](https://www.akgec.ac.in/wp-content/uploads/2023/05/CCC-2020-21.pdf)
[ 2019-20 ](https://www.akgec.ac.in/wp-content/uploads/2023/05/CCC-2019-20.pdf)
[ 2018-19 ](https://www.akgec.ac.in/wp-content/uploads/2023/05/CCC-2018-19.pdf)
[ 2017-18 ](https://www.akgec.ac.in/wp-content/uploads/2023/05/CCC-2017-18.pdf)
Activities
The cell helps students to boost their learning about latest technological trends. The cell is also promoting research work and projects in the field of cloud computing and related technologies.
The cell conducts a series of activities every year few of them are mentioned here.
### 
The Cloud Computing Cell successfully organized an engaging and insightful event
column20: “TechBuzz
column21: which featured Rohit Negi
column22: a renowned YouTuber
column23: tech enthusiast
column24: and industry expert. Rohit Negi is the founder of Coing Army and runs a popular YouTube channel with over 187K subscribers
column25: where he shares valuable insights on technology
column27: and industry trends. He made headlines in 2021 when he secured the highest package in India from Uber
column28: amounting to ₹2.05 crore
column29: with a base package of ₹96 lakh. The event aimed to inspire students and budding technologists by providing them with first-hand industry knowledge and career guidance. The session witnessed an overwhelming response
column30: with more than 120 attendees eager to gain insights from Rohit Negi’s experiences and expertise.\nRohit Negi
column31: widely known for his informative content on technology and career growth
column32: captivated the audience with his personal journey in the tech industry. He shared valuable insights into his early struggles
column33: breakthrough moments
column34: and the lessons he learned along the way. He spoke about the rapid advancements in technology
column35: emphasizing the importance of continuous learning and adaptability to stay ahead in the field.\nDuring the interactive session
column36: he addressed some of the most pressing questions from the audience
column37: covering topics such as career opportunities in cloud computing
column38: software development
column39: content creation
column40: and emerging technologies. He provided practical advice on navigating the ever-changing tech landscape
column43: and self-learning.\nAdditionally
column44: he shared tips on building a personal brand
column45: leveraging online platforms for skill development
column46: and networking effectively within the industry. His words resonated with aspiring engineers
column47: motivating them to embrace challenges
column48: stay curious
column49: and pursue their dreams with determination.\nThe event concluded on a high note
column50: leaving participants motivated and better equipped to take charge of their careers. The Cloud Computing Cell looks forward to organizing more such impactful events to continue inspiring students and fostering a strong tech community within the college.\n### \nThe Cloud Computing Cell successfully conducted “NIMBUS
column51: a hands-on introductory workshop covering Git & GitHub
column52: Cloud Computing
column53: Python Programming
column54: Docker
column55: and Machine Learning on May 24th and 25th 2024 in the Main Seminar Hall. The workshop was open to 1st-year and 2nd-year students of the college
column56: with a registration fee of ₹150. The response was overwhelming
column57: with 100% attendance on both days.\nThe workshop commenced on May 24th 2024 at 10 AM with an inspiring address by Dr. Veena Bharti
column58: who guided the students toward a promising future in the field of technology. The sessions were held from 10 AM to 4 PM on both days
column59: ensuring an immersive learning experience.**Workshop Breakdown**\n🔹 Day 1:The members of the Cloud Computing Cell introduced participants to Git & GitHub
column60: followed by an insightful session on Cloud Computing. The fundamentals of Python programming were also covered
column61: with hands-on exercises to reinforce learning.\n🔹 Day 2:All queries and doubts related to Python were addressed
column62: ensuring conceptual clarity. The participants were then introduced to Docker
column63: where its applications and real-world use cases were demonstrated in detail.\nThe workshop concluded with a mega quiz
column64: featuring questions based on the topics covered over both days. The top performers of the quiz were given a direct interview opportunity for recruitment into the Cloud Computing Cell in the upcoming semester.\nWith an enthusiastic turnout and an engaging learning environment
column65: NIMBUS proved to be a resounding success. The Cloud Computing Cell looks forward to organizing more such impactful and skill-enhancing workshops in the future. \n### \nThe Cloud Computing Cell successfully conducted “SPOCC’24
column66: its annual recruitment drive to onboard talented second-year students into the society. The recruitment process was designed to identify and select the best candidates through a structured evaluation.\n**Recruitment Process:**\n🔹 Phase 1 – Coding & Common Test Round:The first phase consisted of a coding and aptitude test
column67: which was conducted in the college labs from 4:30 PM to 6:30 PM. Several students participated in this rigorous assessment
column68: showcasing their problem-solving and technical skills. Based on their performance
column69: the top 90 candidates were shortlisted for the next stage.\n🔹 Phase 2 – Personal Interviews:The shortlisted candidates proceeded to the interview round
column70: where they were evaluated on their technical expertise
column71: problem-solving abilities
column72: and passion for technology. The interviews focused on various domains
column73: including Web Development
column74: Cloud Computing
column75: and Machine Learning.\nAfter a rigorous selection process
column76: 35 students were chosen as trainees for the Cloud Computing Cell. Out of these
column77: 15 exceptional candidates were selected as permanent members of the society
column78: joining the core team to contribute to future projects
column79: workshops
column80: and initiatives.With SPOCC’24 successfully identifying and recruiting the brightest tech enthusiasts
column81: the Cloud Computing Cell is excited to mentor and work alongside the next generation of innovators.\n### \nThe Cloud Computing Cell
column82: the technical society under the IT Department of Ajay Kumar Garg Engineering College
column83: successfully organized “DevClash
column84: an event designed exclusively for 2nd-year students to showcase their front-end development skills in both web and app development.\n**Event Structure:**\n🔹 Round 1 – Elimination Round: The competition began with an aptitude test consisting of 30 questions
column86: problem-solving
column87: and fundamental development knowledge. Based on their performance
column88: the top 7 teams from each domain (Web and App Development) advanced to the next round. Each team comprised two members.\n🔹 Round 2 – Development Round: In the final round
column89: the shortlisted teams were provided with pre-designed web and app UI mockups. Their task was to replicate the given design through coding
column90: demonstrating their proficiency in front-end development
column91: attention to detail
column92: and implementation skills. The event concluded with top-performing teams from both domains being awarded prize money in recognition of their exceptional development skills.\nWith DevClash providing a competitive yet learning-driven environment
column93: the Cloud Computing Cell continues its mission of nurturing talent and fostering technical excellence among students.\n### \nInformation Technology department in collaboration with department society CLOUD COMPUTING CELL organized 2-days workshop “React-ion""
column94: a code along with an introductory workshop to Web development through React Framework on 10th(Saturday) and 11th(Sunday) of June at Web Technology Lab. 40 students from 1st and 2nd year were registered and actively participated in the workshop.The workshop started on 10th June. The workshop was conducted from 10 AM to 4 PM on 10th and 11th of June.\nOn the first day
column95: Second-year and Third-year members of the Cloud Computing Cell taught about the basics of Web development with HTML and CSS. Students were guided through a code along exercise where they practiced and implemented syntax to develop a webpage. Students were also provided with refreshment before they were introduced to JavaScript language.On the Second day
column96: all issues and queries regarding HTML
column97: CSS and JavaScript were resolved and then all participants were introduced to React Framework and its use was demonstrated. Participants were also encouraged to follow all commands and codes along with the instructor. Workshop concluded with an Introduction to Cloud Computing and its role in the development of students.\nIt was a very informative session with lots of positive feedback by the students who attended the event. Cloud Computing Cell has successfully conducted this workshop and also aspires to conduct more such kinds of events to encourage learning of the new Technical skills and fields.\nThe event was well coordinated by our faculty coordinator Mr. Santosh Mishra (Assistant Professor-IT)
column98:
Mr. Sundeep Raj (Assistant Professor-IT) and all the students ‘members of cloud cell’.
Cloud Computing Cell has successfully conducted this workshop and also aspires to conduct more such kind of events to encourage learning of the new Technical skills and fields.
### 
The Cloud Computing Cell has conducted a workshop from 28th to 29th April 2022 titled as “CloudSplore” . The workshop was conducted under the guidance of Dr. Parneet Kaur and Dr. Abhilasha Singh (Coordinators Cloud Cell).
The Cloud Computing cell has been in successful execution for more than 6 years and has bookmarked itself as the one of the prestigious technical societies of AKGEC
column99: IT Department. In order to continue the trends of the effective learning and capturing intelligent minds to serve the college in even bigger and better way
column100: it is necessary to organize events which help students to gain extra knowledge and sharpen their technical skills. Thus
column101: in this series another workshop ‘Cloudsplore’ was conducted by the cell on 28th and 29th April 2022. This event was open to all first- and second-year students
column102: 140 students were registered for this Workshop.The workshop was carried out in following manner:\n1) Round 1: This Round was conducted in 2 days in which we explained the cloud and its application along with Hands-On-Experience on Virtual Machine creation on AWS and GitHub to all the participants. This round was held at Web technology lab
column103:
IT lab 1 and IT lab 2 on 28th and 29th April at 4 PM.
2) Round 2: This Round was consisted of quiz based on cloud and it`s services such as Virtual Machine creation and GitHub questions which was self-paced to access the basic technical and IQ of the students. The students were shortlisted on the basis of their marks for this round. This round was held online at D2C Platform on 30th April 2022 at 7:00 PM.
The top three winners of the event were awarded with the cash prizes:
**Name** | **Branch** | **Year** | **Prizes**  
---|---|---|---  
Atul Kumar | IT | 1st Year | 1st  
Archas Srivastava | CS | 1st Year | 2nd  
Malika Garg | CS | 1st Year | 3rd  
Finally
column104: everyone present in the workshop appreciated the sessions and desired more sessions to be held which must focus primarily on Cloud Computing and its latest trends and technologies. Some of the main pics of the event are as follows:\n### \nCloud Computing Cell conducted a 9-hour interactive workshop Erudition’20 on AWS
column107:
version control system and other trending topics on IOT. The event included hands on project for deploying home based Personal Cloud Storage. A Raspberry Pi kit worth ₹ 3000 is rewarded to the top performing student in the event.
For this event we received massive participation of registered entries over 400 but due to limited seats available only 70 participants were allowed.

content_chunk: "# Consultancy\n### \nDuring the Covid 19 pandemic
column3:
AKGEC FabLab developed a low cost yet environmental friendly and reusable products – Respirator and Face shield using 3D printing Technology. 
The respirator was developed using Polylactic Acid. The filter material used was disposable mask cloth but any material as per exposed environment can be used. Design considerations such as suitability for average male / female face size with ergonomic characteristics and perfect fit on the face without causing any problems due to prolonged usage were taken into consideration. The weight of the respirator was 47 grams and average cost of manufacture was INR 100.
### 
AKGEC Skills Foundation (ASF) is working very closely with Modern Coach Factory
column4: Rae Bareilly for training and upgradation of the competency of their engineers in Industrial Robotics and Automation. Further to this
column5: MCF has agreed to organize joint In-Plant Training Programs through their Technical Training Centre on Robot Operation & Programming. The first program on “Robot Operation & Programming – In-Plant Training” was conducted at Modern Coach Factory Rae Bareilly during 17-28 September
column6: 2018 for 15 participants.\n### \nAKGEC Skills Foundation (ASF) team lead by Prof. IP Sharma and Mr. Som Ashutosh visited No. 1 & No. 4 Base Repair Depot (BRD) at Kanpur in May
column8: 2018 respectively and No. 7 BRD
column9: Tughlakhabad Air Force Station in August
column10: 2018. No. 7 BRD have sought ASF’s support in conducting repair and life enhancement studies of their Surface to Air Missile Launching Systems. ASF has also been requested to scan and develop a 3D printed model of their Surface to Air Missile Launcher which may be presented to the Prime Minister on the Air Force Day. AKGEC has been attached to Nodal Technological Centres (NTC) of No. 7 BRD
column11: Tughlakhabad
column14: Prof. I. P. Sharma and Mr. Som Ashutosh participated in NTC Symposium organized by 7 BRD
column15: Indian Air Force

column17: Tughlakabad on 27 September
